text.p: Here are highlights from Polish newspapers this morning.
- Heavy rains let up in southern Poland but flood alerts continued. A flood wave on the Oder was expected to reach the southwestern city of Opole last night.

- Poland said it would try to help the Baltic republics enter NATO. Yesterday during the Madrid summit the presidents of Poland and the Czech Republic along with the Hungarian prime minister held talks with the heads of the Baltic states.

- Insurance company ATU had more than 2 million zlotys net profit last year, one million less than in 1995. ATU's collected premiums nearly doubled in comparison with 1995 and deposits have also increased.

- The DRI/McGraw-Hill company which preparing economic forecasts, said Argentina and Poland were among the countries of the lowest investement risk on the so-called emerging markets within next 5 years. Poland was second in the ranking because of continued growth of production efficiency and the lowering of inflation and unemployment levels.

The OECD expects that Poland's GDP should grow by five percent this year and 4.9 percent next year. They claim very good industrial results in the first quarter of 1997 were the driving force behind economic growth. They also said achieving the 13 percent inflation target in 1997 was possible.

Net-Technology, a Warsaw-based computer systems firm, will in September start working on its issue prospectus. Next year the company wants to enter the bourse. The company plans to invest the money from the share issue in the construction of computer networks in Poland. NOTE - Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
